channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Perl Developer and Business Owner? Remote Perl role in UK & EU
item.description: Our clients run a job search engine that has grown from two friends with an idea to a site that receives more than 10 million visits per month. They're looking for a Perl pro with at least three years of experience with high-volume and high-traffic apps and sites, a solid understanding of Object-Oriented Perl (perks if that knowledge includes Moose) and SQL/MySQL and DBIx::Class.

item.title: Someone left the awesome job machine on again… UK remote Perl job
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dancer, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: Good (Perl) Humans Wanted. Remote Perl role in USA
item.description: Most jobs get you paid, but the best ones help you make the world a better place. To increase your karmic bank account while adding dollars and cents at your financial institution, we’ve found a 100% remote role that will let you make a difference from the comfort of your living room. Looking for Perl developers with Catalyst/Mojolicious and DBIx::Class.

item.title: Adventure! Senior Perl roles in Malaysia, Dubai and Malta
item.description: Clever folks know that if you’re lucky, you can earn a living and have an adventure at the same time. Enter our international client: online trading is their game, and — well, we won’t reveal their name just yet, but suffice to say you’ve probably heard of them. Their ideal person has 10 – 20 years of experience with Perl and is dying to have an adventure in a glamorous new locale.

item.title: Boston PM : Ovid+LeoNerd on Corinna - OO in Perl5 Core (live but virtual)
item.description: Tuesday Oct 11th, 2022 07:00 PM Eastern Time (US and Canada)

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: PWC185
item.description: Fun one-liner in Perl for Mask Code task is not to be missed. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Big MAC and Mask
item.description: I am always fascinated by PostScript solution. Thank you Roger for sharing.

item.title: Manipulating characters
item.description: Another cool demo of regex in action. Task analysis is interesting too. Thanks for your contribution.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 185
item.description: Nice use of CPAN module and not re-inventing the wheels. Thanks for sharing the knowledge with us.

item.title: string substitutions
item.description: Lots of Raku magic in action. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 185: MAC Address and Mask Code
item.description: Smart pure regex solutions in Perl and Raku. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 185
item.description: Plenty of different variations on display as always the case with James. You don't want to skip it, highly recommended.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 185
item.description: Beautifully designed one-liner in Raku with exceptionally detailed discussion. Thanks for everything.

item.title: PWC185 - Mask Code
item.description: I can't ignore the questions section. It raises some interesting questions. Thanks for sharing cool solutions.

item.title: PWC185 - MAC Address
item.description: One-liner subroutine in Perl and Raku, very impressive. Thank you.

item.title: Enter the Masked Ball
item.description: As always, detailed task analysis showing the power of regex. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Mask the MAC
item.description: Great demo of substr() in Raku to solve this week challenges. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Challenge 185
item.description: Welcome back to blogging after a break.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 179
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: Meet The Champion - Kueppo Wesley
item.description: Please checkout the interview with the latest champion of The Weekly Challenge.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 185
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Mac Address" and "Mask Code" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 186
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Zip List" and "Unicode Makeover". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: List of new CPAN distributions – Sep 2022
Show error logs on Github Actions - Install developer dependencies first (Test::CSS)
The value of a clean Continuous Integration (CI) system (for Data-Trace)
item.description: Catching Author-test failures

item.title: The deep, the shallow and the ugly (classes)
item.description: Some bits about the code base of Graphics::Toolkit::Color.

item.title: Adding GitHub Actions to Test2::Harness::UI
item.description: A detailed explanation of the GitHub Actions configuration file.

item.title: Building a Perlanet Container
item.description: It is very nice to see Dave got into (or back) to the Docker image building game. More importantly, I did not know that the Perl Planetarium is hosted on GitHub Pages. I guess I might set up a feed-collector of my own using the tools davorg created.

item.title: How I use Yabsm to Manage my Btrfs Snapshots
item.description: Where Yabsm stands for yet another btrfs snapshot manager and Btrfs is "better F S" a filesystem for Linux.

item.title: Add GitHub Actions (CI) to Graphics-Toolkit-Color Perl module
Cryptopals 40 - Implement an E=3 RSA Broadcast attack
Using GitHub Actions (CI) to locate missing test dependencies in Dist::Zilla::PERLSRVDE
CPAN Digger and the Hacktoberfest
item.description: How to use CPAN Digger to find CPAN packages that need a CI. (A new idea: add the CPAN Cover results to the CPAN::Digger page.)

item.title: Feature release 1.32 of Date::Holidays Perl distribution
Look mom I invented colors
item.description: Lichtkind just released Graphics::Toolkit::Color for the purpose to create computationally harmonic color pallets.

item.title: Hacktoberfest 2022
item.description: Flavio does not seem to be impressed. I like the concept of Hacktoberfest, but in recent years it seems the useless PRs have gotten out of hand and the whole project is less fun.

item.title: Release 0.4.0 of my Perl Dist::Zilla GitHub Action
item.description: If your CPAN distribution uses Dist::Zilla, this tool might make it easier to set up GitHub Actions and the process might run much faster as Dist::Zilla is already installed in the image. I have not tried it yet, but this sounds interesting as it can reduce the runtime of the CI by a few minutes.

item.title: Torto AI
item.description: Are you interested to invest some money in the stock market, but don't want to waste time chasing data sources? Are you overwhelmed by the meaningless data dumps from the big web-sites? Try torto.ai.

item.title: Creating a CPAN Author's Guide
item.description: An excellent place to contribute to the Perl ecosystem and to get your Hacktoberfest PR

item.title: Nominate heroes for the 2022 White Camel Awards
#585 - Handle your Pull-Requests, please!
item.description:
Hi there!

I know you are busy with tons of stuff and I know that as an Open Source developer you are most likely just a volunteer, but so are the people who send you Pull-Requests. It is very unpleasant to do the work, even if it small, send the pull-request and then never hear from the author any more.

Looking at my GitHub profile, apparently I created 600 Pull-requests, 530 of them are closed but 70 are still open. Some of them are open since 2011, that is 11 years ago. Some are as small as changing http to https in a URL, accepting (or rejecting) them should not take more than a few second. Finding them might be harder as GitHub does not seem to have a button for that, but you can easily search for them as you can see in my post Listing Pull-request waiting for a user.

So I'd like to ask you to check if there are any Pull-Requests waiting for you and try to clean up the queue.

Hacktoberfest: If you receive a Pull-request during October, if you like it, accept it and consider marking it according to the instructions for maintainers so the PR will be accepted. (Hacktoberfest recognized 11 PRs I sent since registering, none of the repos are marked as participating. I am not sending the PRs for Hacktoberfest, but it would be encouraging to get the recognition.)

Enjoy your week!
item.dc:subject: editorial
